chapter.title: Exporting &ceph; Data via &samba;
chapter.para: This chapter describes how to export data stored in a &ceph; cluster via a &samba;/CIFS share so that you can easily access them from Windows* client machines. It also includes information that will help you configure a &ceph; &samba; gateway to join &ad; in the Windows* domain to authenticate and authorize users.

note.title: &samba; Gateway Performance
note.para: Because of increased protocol overhead and additional latency caused by extra network hops between the client and the storage, accessing &cephfs; via a &samba; Gateway may significantly reduce application performance when compared to native &ceph; clients.

warning.title: Cross Protocol Access
warning.para: Native &cephfs; and NFS clients are not restricted by file locks obtained via Samba, and vice versa. Applications that rely on cross protocol file locking may experience data corruption if &cephfs; backed Samba share paths are accessed via other means.

sect2.title: &samba; Related Packages Installation
sect2.para: To configure and export a &samba; share, the following packages need to be installed: samba-ceph and samba-winbind. If these packages are not installed, install them:

sect2.title: Single Gateway Example
sect2.para: In preparation for exporting a Samba share, choose an appropriate node to act as a &sgw;. The node needs to have access to the &ceph; client network, as well as sufficient CPU, memory, and networking resources.
Failover functionality can be provided with CTDB and the &sle; &hasi;. Refer to for more information on HA setup.

step.para: Make sure that a working &cephfs; already exists in your cluster. For details, see .
Create a &sgw; specific keyring on the &ceph; admin node and copy it to both &sgw; nodes:
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph auth get-or-create client.samba.gw mon 'allow r' \ osd 'allow *' mds 'allow *' -o ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring &prompt.cephuser;scp ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring SAMBA_NODE:/etc/ceph/
step.para: Replace SAMBA_NODE with the name of the Samba gateway node.
The following steps are executed on the &sgw; node. Install Samba together with the &ceph; integration package:
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo zypper in samba samba-ceph

step.para: Replace the default contents of the /etc/samba/smb.conf file with the following:
step.screen:
[global] netbios name = SAMBA-GW clustering = no idmap config * : backend = tdb2 passdb backend = tdbsam # disable print server load printers = no smbd: backgroundqueue = no
[SHARE_NAME] path = / vfs objects = ceph ceph: config_file = /etc/ceph/ceph.conf ceph: user_id = samba.gw read only = no oplocks = no kernel share modes = no

tip.title: Oplocks and Share Modes
tip.para: oplocks (also known as SMB2+ leases) allow for improved performance through aggressive client caching, but are currently unsafe when Samba is deployed together with other &cephfs; clients, such as kernel mount.ceph, FUSE, or &ganesha;.
Currently kernel share modes needs to be disabled in a share running with the &cephfs; vfs module for file serving to work properly.

important.title: Permitting Access
important.para: Since vfs_ceph does not require a file system mount, the share path is interpreted as an absolute path within the &ceph; file system on the attached &ceph; cluster. For successful share I/O, the path's access control list (ACL) needs to permit access from the mapped user for the given Samba client. You can modify the ACL by temporarily mounting via the &cephfs; kernel client and using the chmod, chown or setfacl utilities against the share path. step.para: Start and enable the Samba daemon:
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl start smb.service &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl enable smb.service &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl start nmb.service &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl enable nmb.service

sect2.title: High Availability Configuration

important.title: Transparent Failover Not Supported
important.para: Although a multi-node Samba + CTDB deployment is more highly available compared to the single node (see ), client-side transparent failover is not supported. Applications will likely experience a short outage on &sgw; node failure.

sect2.para: Additionally, two floating virtual IP addresses allow clients to connect to the service no matter which physical node it is running on. 192.168.1.10 is used for cluster administration with Hawk2 and 192.168.2.1 is used exclusively for the CIFS exports. This makes it easier to apply security restrictions later.
The following procedure describes the example installation. More details can be found at .

step.para: Create a &sgw; specific keyring on the &adm; and copy it to both nodes:
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph auth get-or-create client.samba.gw mon 'allow r' \ osd 'allow *' mds 'allow *' -o ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring &prompt.cephuser;scp ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring &si.earth;:/etc/ceph/ &prompt.cephuser;scp ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring &si.mars;:/etc/ceph/

step.para:
SLE-HA setup requires a fencing device to avoid a split brain situation when active cluster nodes become unsynchronized. For this purpose, you can use a &ceph; RBD image with Stonith Block Device (SBD). Refer to
for more details.
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser;ceph osd pool create rbd PG_NUM PGP_NUM replicated &prompt.cephuser;ceph osd pool application enable rbd rbd &prompt.cephuser;rbd -p rbd create sbd01 --size 64M --image-shared

step.para: Prepare &si.earth; and &si.mars; to host the Samba service:
Make sure the following packages are installed before you proceed: ctdb, tdb-tools, and samba (needed for smb.service and nmb.service).
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser.smb;zypper in ctdb tdb-tools samba samba-ceph

step.para: Make sure the services ctdb, smb, and nmb are stopped and disabled:
step.screen: &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl disable ctdb &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl disable smb &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl disable nmb &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl stop smb &prompt.cephuser.smb;sudo systemctl stop nmb

step.para: Open port 4379 of your firewall on all nodes. This is needed for CTDB to communicate with other cluster nodes.
On &si.earth;, create the configuration files for Samba. They will later automatically synchronize to &si.mars;.
Insert a list of private IP addresses of &sgw; nodes in the /etc/ctdb/nodes file. Find more details in the ctdb manual page (man 7 ctdb).
step.screen: &subnetI;.1 &subnetI;.2

step.para: Configure Samba. Add the following lines in the [global] section of /etc/samba/smb.conf. Use the host name of your choice in place of CTDB-SERVER (all nodes in the cluster will appear as one big node with this name). Add a share definition as well, consider SHARE_NAME as an example:
step.screen:
[global] netbios name = SAMBA-HA-GW clustering = yes idmap config * : backend = tdb2 passdb backend = tdbsam ctdbd socket = /var/lib/ctdb/ctdb.socket # disable print server load printers = no smbd: backgroundqueue = no
[SHARE_NAME] path = / vfs objects = ceph ceph: config_file = /etc/ceph/ceph.conf ceph: user_id = samba.gw read only = no oplocks = no kernel share modes = no
step.para: Note that the /etc/ctdb/nodes and /etc/samba/smb.conf files need to match on all &sgw; nodes.
Install and bootstrap the &sle; &ha; cluster.
Register the &sle; &hasi; on &si.earth; and &si.mars;:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;SUSEConnect -r ACTIVATION_CODE -e E_MAIL
&prompt.mars;SUSEConnect -r ACTIVATION_CODE -e E_MAIL

step.para: Install ha-cluster-bootstrap on both nodes:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;zypper in ha-cluster-bootstrap
&prompt.mars;zypper in ha-cluster-bootstrap

step.para: Map the RBD image sbd01 on both &sgw;s via rbdmap.service.
Edit /etc/ceph/rbdmap and add an entry for the SBD image:
step.screen: rbd/sbd01 id=samba.gw,keyring=/etc/ceph/ceph.client.samba.gw.keyring
step.para: Enable and start rbdmap.service:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;systemctl enable rbdmap.service && systemctl start rbdmap.service &prompt.mars;systemctl enable rbdmap.service && systemctl start rbdmap.service
step.para: The /dev/rbd/rbd/sbd01 device should be available on both &sgw;s.
Initialize the cluster on &si.earth; and let &si.mars; join it.
step.screen: &prompt.earth;ha-cluster-init
&prompt.mars;ha-cluster-join -c earth

important.para: During the process of initialization and joining the cluster, you will be interactively asked whether to use SBD. Confirm with y and then specify /dev/rbd/rbd/sbd01 as a path to the storage device.

step.para: Check the status of the cluster. You should see two nodes added in the cluster:
step.screen:
&prompt.earth;crm status 2 nodes configured 1 resource configured
Online: [ earth mars ]
Full list of resources:
admin-ip (ocf::heartbeat:IPaddr2): Started earth

step.para: Execute the following commands on &si.earth; to configure the CTDB resource:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;crm configure &prompt.crm.conf;primitive ctdb ocf:heartbeat:CTDB params \ ctdb_manages_winbind="false" \ ctdb_manages_samba="false" \ ctdb_recovery_lock="!/usr/lib64/ctdb/ctdb_mutex_ceph_rados_helper ceph client.samba.gw cephfs_metadata ctdb-mutex" ctdb_socket="/var/lib/ctdb/ctdb.socket" \ op monitor interval="10" timeout="20" \ op start interval="0" timeout="200" \ op stop interval="0" timeout="100" &prompt.crm.conf;primitive nmb systemd:nmb \ op start timeout="100" interval="0" \ op stop timeout="100" interval="0" \ op monitor interval="60" timeout="100" &prompt.crm.conf;primitive smb systemd:smb \ op start timeout="100" interval="0" \ op stop timeout="100" interval="0" \ op monitor interval="60" timeout="100" &prompt.crm.conf;group g-ctdb ctdb nmb smb &prompt.crm.conf;clone cl-ctdb g-ctdb meta interleave="true" &prompt.crm.conf;commit
step.para: The binary /usr/lib64/ctdb/ctdb_mutex_ceph_rados_helper in the configuration option ctdb_recovery_lock has the parameters CLUSTER_NAME, CEPHX_USER, RADOS_POOL, and RADOS_OBJECT, in this order.

An extra lock-timeout parameter can be appended to override the default value used (10 seconds). A higher value will increase the CTDB recovery master failover time, whereas a lower value may result in the recovery master being incorrectly detected as down, triggering flapping failovers.
Add a clustered IP address:
step.screen: &prompt.crm.conf;primitive ip ocf:heartbeat:IPaddr2 params ip=192.168.2.1 \ unique_clone_address="true" \ op monitor interval="60" \ meta resource-stickiness="0" &prompt.crm.conf;clone cl-ip ip \ meta interleave="true" clone-node-max="2" globally-unique="true" &prompt.crm.conf;colocation col-with-ctdb 0: cl-ip cl-ctdb &prompt.crm.conf;order o-with-ctdb 0: cl-ip cl-ctdb &prompt.crm.conf;commit
step.para: If unique_clone_address is set to true, the IPaddr2 resource agent adds a clone ID to the specified address, leading to three different IP addresses. These are usually not needed, but help with load balancing. For further information about this topic, see .
Check the result:
step.screen: &prompt.earth;crm status Clone Set: base-clone [dlm] Started: [ factory-1 ] Stopped: [ factory-0 ] Clone Set: cl-ctdb [g-ctdb] Started: [ factory-1 ] Started: [ factory-0 ] Clone Set: cl-ip [ip] (unique) ip:0 (ocf:heartbeat:IPaddr2): Started factory-0 ip:1 (ocf:heartbeat:IPaddr2): Started factory-1

step.para: Test from a client machine. On a Linux client, run the following command to see if you can copy files from and to the system:
step.screen: &prompt.root;smbclient //192.168.2.1/myshare
